properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow continues for Arviat until Monday night. Total snowfall accumulations of 20 to 25 cm are expected with the heaviest snow coming later this afternoon and this evening. As winds increase throughout the day, gusting up to 70 km/h at times, reduced visibilities in blowing snow are also expected later this afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-16T01:38:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-15T09:39:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2552014754.2021
Area: Arviat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An Arctic air mass combined with strong northwesterly winds will give wind chill values near -38 this morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-15T16:59:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-15T08:27:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2026810994.2021

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief, intense snowfall is expected. Visibilities will be rapidly reduced due to the heavy snow. Further snowfall: 5 cm except 20 to 30 in snow squalls. Locations: the tip of Cape St. Francis, the Bay de Verde Peninsula, and the Clarenville vicinity. Time span: today and this evening. Remarks: A snow squall from the northern Avalon peninsula to the Clarenville vicinity is expected to meander around the general area today. Potentially significant accumulations are possible under this squall. Conditions are expected to improve this evening as the squall dissipates. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-15T23:47:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-15T07:48:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1717391038.2021
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, St. John's and vicinity, Clarenville and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow continue. These conditions will persist until later this morning, when winds will begin to weaken. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-15T21:34:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-15T08:26:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2715935111.2021
Area: Kugluktuk
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR QUESNEL The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Northern Health Authority has issued a Dust Advisory for Quesnel because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with chronic conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, and diabetes, respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, and older adults. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce particulate matter exposure. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-03-16T03:29:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-03-15T11:30:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4266192795.2021
Area: Cariboo - north including Quesnel
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of heavy snowfall will continue tonight for areas around Great Slave Lake. Snowfall will re-intensify tonight in areas around Great Slave Lake North Arm and East Arm. Another 5 to 10 cm of snow may fall tonight bringing total amounts up to 15 to 25 cm. This new band of snowfall may develop north of Yellowknife and Lutsel K'e. Snow will taper off by Monday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-15T19:36:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-15T03:37:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3393484647.2021
Area: Yellowknife Region, North Slave Region including Wekweeti - Whati - Behchoko, Lutsel K'e Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada
